### How Childhood Vaccines Work  

1. **Basic idea – “training” the immune system**  
   - **Natural infection**: When a virus or bacterium invades, the immune system learns to recognize its unique proteins (antigens). It creates antibodies and memory cells that can fight the pathogen if it shows up again.  
   - **Vaccination**: A vaccine gives the immune system a **safe, controlled exposure** to a piece of the pathogen (or a harmless version of it). The immune system mounts a response and creates the same kind of memory without the person having to suffer the disease and its complications.  

2. **Types of vaccines used in children**  

| Vaccine type | What it contains | How it works | Typical examples in the childhood schedule |
|--------------|------------------|--------------|--------------------------------------------|
| **Live‑attenuated** | Weakened but still living microbes | Replicate a little, stimulating a strong, long‑lasting response (often with one dose) | Measles‑mumps‑rubella (MMR), varicella (chickenpox), rotavirus, oral polio (in some countries) |
| **Inactivated (killed)** | Whole microbe that has been killed | Can’t replicate; the immune system sees the antigens and makes a response, usually needs multiple doses | Inactivated polio vaccine (IPV), hepatitis A, rabies (if given to children) |
| **Subunit / protein‑based** | Only specific proteins or sugars from the pathogen (e.g., capsular polysaccharide, surface protein) | Focuses the immune response on the most protective parts; very safe because no whole organism | DTaP (diphtheria‑tetanus‑pertussis), Hib (Haemophilus influenzae type b), hepatitis B, pneumococcal conjugate (PCV) |
| **Toxoid** | Inactivated toxin produced by the bacteria | Immune system learns to neutralize the toxin rather than the bacterium itself | DTaP (diphtheria & tetanus toxoids) |
| **mRNA** (newer) | Messenger RNA that instructs cells to make a harmless piece of the pathogen’s spike protein | Cells produce the protein, the immune system recognizes it and builds immunity; does not contain live virus | COVID‑19 vaccines (e.g., Pfizer‑BioNTech, Moderna) now approved for children ≥6 months in many countries |
| **Viral vector** | A harmless virus (often adenovirus) engineered to carry a gene for a pathogen protein | The vector delivers the gene; host cells make the protein, prompting immunity | Some COVID‑19 vaccines (e.g., Janssen, AstraZeneca) – not yet part of routine U.S. childhood schedule but used in some regions |

3. **How immunity is measured**  
   - **Antibody titers**: Blood tests can quantify the amount of specific antibodies produced after vaccination.  
   - **Cell‑mediated immunity**: T‑cell responses are also important, especially for live‑attenuated vaccines, but they are harder to measure routinely.  
   - **Correlates of protection**: For many vaccines, a certain antibody level is known to predict protection; for others (e.g., pertussis), the relationship is less precise, which is why booster doses are recommended.

---

### Main Benefits of Childhood Vaccination  

| Category | What it means for an individual child | What it means for the community (population level) |
|----------|--------------------------------------|----------------------------------------------------|
| **Prevention of disease** | Drastically lowers the chance of getting the targeted infection (often >90 % efficacy after the full series). | Fewer cases overall → less strain on health‑care systems, fewer school absences, lower mortality. |
| **Prevention of severe complications** | Many vaccine‑preventable diseases can cause pneumonia, meningitis, encephalitis, permanent organ damage, or death. Vaccines stop those outcomes. | Reduces the burden of long‑term disability (e.g., hearing loss from meningitis, limb loss from polio). |
| **Herd immunity** | Even children who can’t be vaccinated (e.g., due to severe immunodeficiency, certain allergies) are protected when enough others are immune. | Outbreaks become rare; the community can eliminate diseases (e.g., measles eliminated in many high‑coverage regions). |

## 1. Measles (Rubeola)

### 1.1 Typical presentation (unvaccinated child)
| Age group | Common signs & symptoms | Typical duration |
|----------|--------------------------|------------------|
| 6 months–5 years (most cases) | High fever (often > 40 °C/104 °F), cough, runny nose, red eyes, Koplik spots inside the mouth, followed 2–4 days later by a maculopapular rash that spreads head‑to‑toe. | Fever 7–10 days; rash 5–7 days; most children recover fully. |

> **Key point:** Even the “mild” course can become life‑threatening because the virus spreads throughout the body and can damage many organ systems.

### 1.2 Serious complications (incidence per 1,000 measles cases, where available)

| Complication | Approx. incidence (unvaccinated) | Typical outcome / mortality | Comments |
|--------------|--------------------------------|-----------------------------|----------|
| **Pneumonia (viral or secondary bacterial)** | 1–6 % (higher in infants < 1 yr and malnourished children) | 5–15 % of pneumonia deaths in measles outbreaks | Leading cause of measles‑related death. |
| **Encephalitis (brain inflammation)** | 0.05–0.1 % (≈ 1 per 1,000–2,000 cases) | Case‑fatality ≈ 10–20 %; 25 % of survivors have permanent neurological deficits (e.g., cognitive delay, seizures). | Often occurs 1–2 weeks after rash onset. |
| **Acute otitis media (middle‑ear infection)** | 5–10 % | Usually resolves with antibiotics, but can lead to hearing loss if recurrent. | More common in children < 2 years. |

### 1.3 Mortality
- **Global estimate (pre‑COVID‑19, 2019):** ~ 140,000 measles deaths worldwide, > 95 % in children < 5 years.  
- **High‑income countries:** Deaths are rare (< 1 per 10 million births) but still occur when vaccination coverage drops; e.g., the 2019 U.S. outbreak (667 cases) produced 2 deaths and 4 cases of encephalitis.  
- **Low‑resource settings:** Outbreaks in refugee camps or regions with < 80 % coverage can see mortality rates of 1–3 % among cases.

### 1.4 What the measles vaccine does
- **Two‑dose schedule (MMR)** provides **~ 97 %** protection after the second dose.  
- By preventing infection, it eliminates the entire cascade of complications listed above.
